greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Integers 1 to 2*k followed by integers 1 to 2*k + 2 and so on.
comment: Also the numerator of the fraction in the continued fraction expansion of sqrt(n) for nonsquare n = 2,3,5,6,7... . E.g., for n = 7,
3 is the 5th entry in the table. sqrt(1) and sqrt(4) are not included because 1 and 4 are squares." (End)
A074294 is the natural fractal sequence of A002061; the corresponding natural interspersion is A194011; see A194029 for definitions. - _Clark Kimberling_, Aug 17 2011
It appears that this is also a triangle read by rows in which row n lists the first 2*n positive integers, n >= 1 (see example). - _Omar E. Pol_, May 29 2012
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
formula: G.f.: x/(1-x)^2 - (2*x/(1-x))*sum(k>=1, k*x^(k^2+k)).  That sum is related to Jacobi theta functions. - _Robert Israel_, Jan 05 2015
a(n) = n + A000194(n) - A053187(n). - _Robert Israel_, Jan 05 2015
example: Written as a triangle the sequence begins:
mathematica: A074294[n_] := n - 2*Binomial[Floor[1/2 + Sqrt[n]], 2] (* _Enrique Pérez Herrero_, Apr 14 2010 *)
results.author: _Michael Somos_, Aug 20 2002
